title: Sleep Support: An Individual Randomized Controlled Trial
summary:
Key ideas
- Scott tries Sleep Support to improve his sleep quality and wakes up naturally at 9am on the first night.
- He conducts a randomized controlled trial for 24 nights on Sleep Support vs. placebo pills to monitor his subjective sleep experience.
- The results showed no difference in sleep quality and the effect Scott observed was due to a placebo effect.
- Despite Sleep Support not working, Scott considers the experiment successful as he is waking up an hour earlier and not feeling more tired.

Key learnings
- Controlled self-experimentation can be a useful method in evaluating the effects of supplements.
- Placebo effects can impact sleep quality, and external cues like checking the clock can influence wake-up time.
- The success of a biohacking experiment can sometimes be subjective.

Key questions
- Does Sleep Support work for people with insomnia or other sleep disorders?
- How can self-experimenters better account for placebo effects in their experiments?
- What other external cues can affect sleep quality and wake-up time?
